awd_titl_txt: Gravitational-Wave Data Science with a LIGO at Caltech
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research in gravitational wave detector commissioning and characterization, as well as data analysis and it addresses the priority areas of NSF's "Windows on the Universe" Big Idea. Gravitational-wave (GW) astronomy has entered a new era, when detected events (so far, from the merger of compact binary systems: binary black holes and binary neutron stars) will become frequent. The Advanced LIGO detectors are continuously improving their sensitivity to GWs; this will result in unprecedented rates of discoveries  of compact object mergers, and the potential for many discoveries of GWs from other astrophysical sources. Whole new classes of sources may be discovered.  These observations will enable a wealth of studies and new scientific results in astronomy, cosmology, and fundamental physics.  Observations of binary black hole mergers are used to understand stellar evolution and the formation, evolution and death of binaries. They enable uniquely powerful tests of general relativity as a theory of gravity in the strong-field, highly-relativistic regime where detectable GWs are produced. Observations of binary neutron star mergers enable constraints on the nuclear equation of state, unique measurements of the local Hubble-Lemaitre parameter, studies of gamma-ray burst physics, and insights into the origins of the heavy elements in the universe (including gold, platinum and uranium).  All of these studies are made possible through the construction and operation of the incredibly sensitive LIGO and Virgo detectors. The Caltech group, working with the LIGO Laboratory and LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC), continuously improves the detectors' sensitivity, precisely calibrates the strain data, characterizes detector behavior to evaluate and improve data quality, and releases the data to the public. These studies also depend crucially on the ability to identify weak GW signals from astrophysical sources in the noisy data, using highly optimized search pipelines. We also use the scientific computing required to analyze LIGO data as a tool to engage high school juniors and seniors in the local area in gravitational-wave physics and astronomy, introducing programming and more broadly applying the scientific method through hands-on GW data science projects.

Our work is devoted to discovering and analyzing gravitational-wave (GW) signals in the LIGO, Virgo and KAGRA detectors during LIGO's observing runs O3 and O4. The proposed work focuses on: (a) Identifying GW signals from compact binary mergers in data from LIGO, Virgo, and KAGRA, using both of the LSC ``flagship'' search pipelines, PyCBC and gstlal; (b) using the Hidden Markov Model Viterbi algorithm to search for long-duration burst GWs from compact binary mergers, continuous GWs (CGWs) from newly-formed, rapidly spinning neutron stars in our galaxy, and other sources that produce narrow-band signals with potentially wandering central frequency; and (c) validation of candidate events (including CGW candidates) found by these pipelines, with special attention to data quality, calibration, and search pipeline specifics. We will build on our existing expertise and experience in all of these efforts, and extend them to the era of frequent detections by automating routine tasks. We will exploit our expertise in low-latency data handling, strain calibration, detector characterization and data quality evaluation, and search pipelines. The results of these efforts will make it possible to make confident detections of GW events as they become frequent, and make the information obtained available to the LSC, to the astronomical community, and to the public, promptly, so that they can be fully exploited by those communities to advance gravitational-wave astronomy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF Gravity award supported the research of Caltech Professor Alan Weinstein (3 months), Senior Scientist Jonah Kanner (3 months), postdoctoral scholars Ling (Lilli) Sun (12 mo), Colm Talbot (11 mo), Arianna Renzini (5 mo); and graduate students Alvin Li (36 mo), Rico Lo (13 mo), Liting Xiao (36 mo), Ethan Payne (4 mo).

Our research accomplishments are at the heart of the field of observational gravitational wave physics and astrophysics, using data from the LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA (LVK) detector network. Most of it is pursued in close collaboration with the worldwide LVK Collaborations, and with colleagues in Caltech Physics and Astronomy departments. The products of our research are publications in major research journals (Physical Review, Astrophysics Journal, Classical and Quantum Gravity), software packages, and data releases. 

* Searches for Compact Binary Coalescence (CBC) events in data from LIGO-Virgo O3 (2019-2020) run: We made major contributions to the search for weak gravitational-wave (GW) signals in noisy detector data, resulting in the Gravitational-Wave Transient Catalogs GWTC-2 and GWTC-3 (https://gwosc.org/eventapi/html/GWTC/), comprising 82 confident detected events (in addition to the 11 events we detected in 2015-2017); most of these were binary black hole (BBH) mergers. In collaboration with the LVK, we made major contributions to three full-LVK papers on GWTC catalogs. We identified, analyzed, and published four full-LVK papers on several exceptional events, including a binary neutron star (BNS) merger GW190425, the highest mass BBH event observed so far GW190521, and the highest mass-ratio BBH event GW190412. Four small-author-list "methods" papers on search methods, optimization, and efficacy were published.

* CBC Parameter Estimation: Contributions to the development, testing, and application of BILBY (Bayesian Inference Library for compact binary coalescences) to analyze the properties (masses and spins) of the binary components for each merger event. Five small-author-list "methods" papers were published.

* Population of merging compact binaries inferred using gravitational waves through GWTC-3: We analyzed the distribution of masses and spins of component neutron stars and black holes in merging binaries, estimating and correcting for observational biases. We contributed to two full-LVK papers and one short-author-list methods paper, and one public data release.

* Tests of general relativity with binary black holes: Using events from GWTC-2 and GWTC-3, we searched for GW signals with polarizations beyond those allowed by general relativity (GR) and found no evidence for them. We searched for gravitational-wave "echoes" following BBH merger signals that could be evidence for black hole mimickers (exotic compact objects) and found no evidence for them. We contributed to two full-LVK papers and three short-author-list methods papers.

* Strong gravitational lensing of GW signals: We developed efficient methods to identify gravitationally-lensed gravitational waves from distant CBC mergers that are lensed by intervening massive galaxies or galaxy clusters berore arriving at our detectors. This can produce nearly identical signals from the same sky location but at different times and with different amplitudes (lensed event pairs). We applied these methods to data from the O3 run, finding no significant candidate event pairs. These methods are now being applied to data from the fourth LVK observing run (2023-2024). We contributed to five methods papers, two full-LVK results papers, and one major software package.

* Stochastic GW background (SGWB): We developed improved methods to search for a SGWB, including a new analysis pipeline (pygwb) and a large-scale "mock data challenge" to test all elements of the analysis for accuracy and precision. The methods were applied in data from the LVK O3 run, with no confident detection. We contributed to three full-LVK papers, six short-author-list methods papers, and one major software package.

* Continuous gravitational wave (CGW) detection using Hidden Markov Model (HMM) tracking: We developed and applied new techniques for identifying CGS from rapidly spinning neutron stars and (hypothetical) ultralight boson clouds around spinning black holes. No signals were found in data from O3. We contributed to three short-author-list methods papers.

* Precision calibration of the LIGO detector strain: We contributed to one LVK paper and one small-author-list paper.

* Open data: We contributed to the preparation of the strain data and GWTC catalog data from the LVK O3 run (2019-2020) for public release on the GW Open Science Center (gwosc.org), resulting in two full-LVK papers.

* Graduate student training: two graduate students successfully defended their Caltech PhD theses, and two more made major progress in their thesis projects.

* Undergraduate and high school student research mentoring: We mentored the GW data science research of 26 students in summers of 2020 - 2023. We mentored many student participants of annual GW Open Data Workshops in the years 2020 - 2023. We hosted visits of local and international high school groups at Caltech, and presented lectures, workshops and hands-on coding exercises with them.
